abstract: The chief executives of Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase bought hundreds of thousands of shares in their respective companies in the last week, offering a sign of confidence as the banking industry struggles with climbing credit losses and a deep recession.
lead_paragraph: The chief executives of Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase bought hundreds of thousands of shares in their respective companies in the last week, offering a sign of confidence as the banking industry struggles with climbing credit losses and a deep recession.

headline.main: Bank of America and JPMorgan Chiefs Buy Stock

abstract: Investors filed a proposed class-action lawsuit against Bank of America in New York on Wednesday, accusing the bank and its officers of failing to disclose risks in its January 1 takeover of Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: Investors filed a proposed class-action lawsuit against Bank of America in New York on Wednesday, accusing the bank and its officers of failing to disclose risks in its January 1 takeover of Merrill Lynch.

headline.main: Investors Sue Bank Of America Over Merrill Merger
Thain Resigns From Bank of America

abstract: Even as news broke that John Thain was on his way out at Bank of America, there were reports that Mr. Thain oversaw an expensive overhaul of his office on his way in to Merrill Lynch.
snippet: Even as news broke that John Thain was on his way out at Bank of America, there were reports that Mr. Thain oversaw an expensive overhaul of his office on his way in to Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: Even as news broke that John A. Thain was on his way out at Bank of America, there were reports that Mr. Thain oversaw an expensive redecoration of his office on his way into Merrill Lynch.

headline.main: Thain’s Office Overhaul Said to Cost $1.2 Million

abstract: John Thain loses his job, and his reputation.
snippet: John Thain loses his job, and his reputation.
lead_paragraph: The departure of John Thain from Bank of America provides another reminder of how Wall Streeters have come to see themselves as entitled to pay that would seem excessive even if their companies were not failing.
